Award.AwardTitle: The atmosphere of Mars: Observations of thermal tides at, above, and around Gale crater from the surface and from orbit
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to use both landed and orbital measurements of atmospheric properties on Mars, in order to study thermal tides in that planet's atmosphere. Broader impacts of the work include training of a female postdoctoral researcher, and improved understanding of thermal tides on an Earth-like planet that is not Earth which could inform terrestrial atmospheric science.

Measurements from the Curiosity rover would be coupled with orbital data to explore thermal tides in the vicinity of Gale Crater. The model results would provide an opportunity to separate the effects of migrating and non-migrating tides, and would also inform Mars global climate modelling development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermal tides in the atmosphere of Mars have two main effects. 1. Landers on the surface of Mars experience diurnal and semi-diurnal variations in surface pressure. 2. Orbital measurements of the atmosphere aloft show diurnal and semi-diurnal migrating and non-migrating variations. Despite being caused by the same physical process, connections between these two effects have not been well-established. This work was motivated by the existence of simultaneous landed (Curiosity) and orbital (Mars Climate Sounder on Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter) observations at Gale Crater. Another potential application is in using orbital observations of the atmosphere to predict surface pressures that will be experienced by a future lander.


Gale Crater proved to be a challenging case: the local topography of this large crater affects the meteorological conditions experienced by the Curiosity rover and disrupts connections between the local view from the rover and the global view acquired above the rover by Mars Climate Sounder on Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. Therefore we focused out efforts on an idealized case: conditions at the Viking Lander 1 site as simulated by the Mars Climate Database, which is a realistic simulation of climate conditions on Mars.

 

We found that semi-diurnal surface pressure variations can be predicted reasonably well by extrapolation downwards of atmospheric observations of tidal effects. Diurnal surface pressure variations are not predicted well by this extrapolation, which likely reflects differences in the structure of the diurnal and semi-diurnal tidal effects.
